linkTarget.anchoringText: Handil field, discovered in 1974, is an oil and gas field located in internal axis of modern Mahakam Delta in East Kalimantan, Indonesia. The field comprises over 550 hydrocarbon accumulations from depth ~ 200mSS to 3300mSS in structurally stacked and compartmentalized fluvio-deltaic sands. Handil reservoirs were divided into several zones, Shallow (very shallow, shallow & upper), Main, Lower, and Deep zone. Shallow zone to Main zone are known as “Oil Pool”, while the bottom of Main zone down to Deep zone are known as “Gas Pool” (Fig.1).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: Handil field location and structural cross section

formatted-caption.caption-text: Handil field location and structural cross section

linkTarget.anchoringText: Shallow reservoirs are supported by strong aquifer; hence pressure data is not reliable to assist in defining the compartmentalization in the same reservoir segment. Dynamic synthesis was then performed on 36 reservoir layers based on priority list to evaluate and capture such heterogeneity. Figure 2 illustrates iteration process between static and dynamic synthesis. The objectives of the dynamic synthesis are:

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: General workflow of the study, Geological & Reservoir part

formatted-caption.caption-text: General workflow of the study, Geological & Reservoir part

linkTarget.anchoringText: The geomodel update was built with more robust input data (i.e. initial & actual contact, dynamic region) and methodology in order to better capture the reservoir heterogeneity and better understand the uncertainty (Fig.3). The model has delivered re-estimation of initial oil in place, actual oil in place and sweet spot map that became the basis of locating potential future Shallow Zone wells. The objectives and workflow of interest are:

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: Workflow of geomodeling 2015 in shallow zone

formatted-caption.caption-text: Workflow of geomodeling 2015 in shallow zone

linkTarget.anchoringText: The example of this workflow can be seen in Figure 4, reservoir 10-3S3 initially had flat OWC but after production for several years it’s confirmed we have dynamic heterogeneity due to production well distribution and static heterogeneity related to facies and sand distribution. This heterogeneity depicted in the 2D net sand map and the 3D model.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: Workflow of creating actual contact region in 3D model from actual contact definition

formatted-caption.caption-text: Workflow of creating actual contact region in 3D model from actual contact definition

linkTarget.anchoringText: The ultimate drainage area of existing production wells was then introduced to the net actual pay map to estimate the future contact movement. It was calculated based on estimated ultimate reserves (EUR) of each production wells in reservoir level and structurally limited by the top perforation. Decline curve analysis (Fig.5) was used to calculate the 1EUR.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Decline curve analysis methodology and the drainage radius formula

formatted-caption.caption-text: Decline curve analysis methodology and the drainage radius formula

linkTarget.anchoringText: The actual net pay oil map was then cut with the ultimate drainage radius until top of perforation, resulted as sweet spot map or un-swept area which represent the future remaining net pay map. Figure 6 illustrates the sweetspot definition and the example of actual sweet spot map.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: a. Schematic illustration of sweet spot; b. Example of actual & sweet spot map

formatted-caption.caption-text: a. Schematic illustration of sweet spot; b. Example of actual & sweet spot map

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Example of actual & sweet spot map

linkTarget.anchoringText: Blind test for the sweetspot result was performed on 2016 wells to check the accuracy of the netpay prediction from the geomodel. From this blind test, it can be concluded that the shallow geomodel gives quite good net pay prediction despite its tendency to be slightly pessimistic. The main uncertainties are the fluid status which affected by production and sand occurrence in some reservoirs. Summary of blind test result can be seen in the Figure 7.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Blind test of future net pay – Sweet spot

formatted-caption.caption-text: Blind test of future net pay – Sweet spot

linkTarget.anchoringText: The estimated maximum wells for each reservoir compartment will be used as control limit in determine well catalogue. This value will limit the number of wells that penetrating each reservoir compartment. Monte Carlo technique was used to define the maximum wells for each reservoir compartment. Main parameters that used in the calculation are future ROIP and future well reserves. Figure 8 illustrates the workflow to calculate the maximum wells for each compartment.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Maximum wells per Reservoir Compartment Workflow

formatted-caption.caption-text: Maximum wells per Reservoir Compartment Workflow

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 9 shows example of future well or perforation reserves calculation methodology. Blind test was performed in 8 reservoir segment to check the validity of the reserves calculation methodology. Main uncertainties in this methodology are the production allocation and the estimated ultimate reserves. Blind test was performed on 2012 – 2014 wells, which have less uncertainty in production allocation since we have representative PLT data and the production decline trend already obvious. Based on the blind test result (Fig.10), post drilling reserves estimation is in good agreement with the actual reserves realization, total difference ~6%.

Figure 9 shows example of future well or perforation reserves calculation methodology. Blind test was performed in 8 reservoir segment to check the validity of the reserves calculation methodology. Main uncertainties in this methodology are the production allocation and the estimated ultimate reserves. Blind test was performed on 2012 – 2014 wells, which have less uncertainty in production allocation since we have representative PLT data and the production decline trend already obvious. Based on the blind test result (Fig.10), post drilling reserves estimation is in good agreement with the actual reserves realization, total difference ~6%.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Blind test of future reserves realization

formatted-caption.caption-text: Blind test of future reserves realization

linkTarget.anchoringText: Well catalogue was derived from the stacked sweet spot map. Figure 11 ilustrates the workflow to build the well catalogue. Preliminary evaluation was performed with cone approach from existing well clusters and limited by drilling envelope for HSO well. The cone approach was performed in 6 well clusters which feasible to reach our sweet spot. The example of this approach can be seen in Figure 12.

Well catalogue was derived from the stacked sweet spot map. Figure 11 ilustrates the workflow to build the well catalogue. Preliminary evaluation was performed with cone approach from existing well clusters and limited by drilling envelope for HSO well. The cone approach was performed in 6 well clusters which feasible to reach our sweet spot. The example of this approach can be seen in Figure 12.
